Christofer, it's an interesting idea but I think it may be difficult 
to im=
plement in practice because of the nonlinear relationship among 
different =
components of the solution.  That is, just because some 
things change or a=
re updated more than others during learning does 
not imply that they shoul=
d continue to do so or even that it was a 
good idea in the first place (be=
cause the problem might be 
deceptive).  It's a pretty complicated topic bu=
t I think the 
fundamental issue is that evolutionary computation is effect=
ive in 
part because it avoids trying to excplicitly assign credit to the 
=
separate parts of a solution.  So when we move to trying to extract 
explic=
it information about what belongs with what, we are somewhat 
undoing this =
implicit appeal.

Nevertheless, the idea that solutions need some kind of m=
odularity 
or at least a pattern behind them makes sense.  It's just the 
a=
pproach that is the tricky issue.  Have you taken a look at 
HyperNEAT?  It=
 is able to evolve networks with large-scale patterns 
that can be modular =
to varying degrees.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "christofer_fransson=
" 
<christofer_fransson@...> wrote:
>
> Dear all,
> 
> The human brain has =
different areas that solve different kind of
> problems. My question is if =
you think it is a good idea to try
> encouraging a network to divide a prob=
lem into smaller sub problems
> and then solve it.
> 
> This is my thought:=

> 
> - Let say that every neuron has 3 coordinates (x,y,z) 
> - Assuming t=
hat you can tell which neurons were performing well in 
one
> epoch 
> (Bac=
kprop run, network weights that didn't have to be changed much 
etc)
> - Al=
l those nodes should "gravitate" towards each other
> - Nodes close to each=
 other have a higher probability to form a
> connection.
> 
> The result sh=
ould be a network that in someway tries to be modular.
> Next step should b=
e to see if it is possible to do individual 
training
> of different areas =
of the network.
> 
> I mean when you learn math and when you are painting, =
different 
areas
> of the brain is active.
> 
> Comments?
> 
> Br,

ofer
